content:
Spiny hatchetfish live in the deep sea and are rarely seen.
An old and obscure manuscript once recorded that, should one encounter rows of vertical lights in the pitch-black depths, it means one's not far from the underwater city.
Multiple studies by later generations have proven that the "vertical lights" are very likely to be spiny hatchetfish. As for the "underwater city," well, that remains a mystery.

The striped bumblebee shrimp have yellow and black stripes that are very conspicuous in the ocean, just like the bees on land.
If we follow the conventional train of thought, naturally, the bumblebee shrimp should also behave accordingly — weaving through beautiful coral and feeding on debris, just like the bees collect nectar among flowers.
However, in reality, they much prefer forming a symbiotic relationship with inconspicuous echinoderms like sea urchins and sea cucumbers.
Such a habit seems to render its evolved bee-like colors useless, but life's purpose is rarely so easily defined.

The coffee clearwing moth is named for its preference to feed on the flowers of coffee plants.
In areas without coffee plants, the moth leans toward cape jasmine flowers.
If you shake the cape jasmine shrub and several "black strip-like objects" fall, this is the sign to be on alert. The coffee clearwing moth will only produce black larvae when the population density is too high within their habitat.

The pao puffer is small in size but has a notoriously irritable attitude.
When angered, it swallows water or air to inflate its loose abdominal skin, turning itself into a "balloon."
However, this often causes the fish to flip over due to buoyancy, exposing its vulnerable belly above water — an act of self-sabotage in the eyes of predators from above.

The overall shape of the fire eel closely resembles that of a moray eel, but taxonomically, it belongs to the Synbranchiformes order and is more closely related to asian swamp eels.
Despite this, fishing enthusiasts still prefer to nickname it the "firespark eel" rather than the "firespark swamp eel."

The sunny bream is a famous panfish because it fits perfectly inside a frying pan with no chopping required. Combined with their eagerness to bite, they are also a favorite among novice anglers.
However, it's worth noting that sunny bream existed long before the invention of frying pans, so no, it's definitely not "born for the pan."

The painted lobster has vibrant colors all over its body, save for the two plain white antennae on its head.
Favoring ambush tactics from reefs, it often hides between rocks, exposing only its white antennae to scout and keep vigil at the entrance.
Unfamiliar observers might even be startled by these mysterious white appendages that come out of nowhere.

The golden turtle beetle possesses a metallic, beautiful sheen, but beneath its lovely exterior lies a lifestyle that constantly harms plants.
When faced with danger, it adopts the strategy of playing dead. Therefore, to protect the plants, even if you see a motionless, overturned golden turtle beetle on the ground, do not walk away. Instead, why not "introduce" it to the net?

The veil hook moth's wings are semi-transparent, providing a natural "invisibility" advantage in any environment.
However, the quality of these transparent wings is inferior to that of scale-powder wings, resulting in slightly weaker wind resistance for the veil hook moth.
Even a passing light breeze could send its body spinning. Life must be inconvenient this way.

The green pilchard typically moves in schools.
It's said that green pilchard caught by fishing boats suffer from low activity. In order to keep them fresh till their destination, fishermen would add a catfish to the school, so it can agitate them and keep them moving.
The fact of the matter is, since most catfish are freshwater species, the idea that they are used to agitate pilchard from salt waters is a bit of a stretch.

The aurora swallowtail is a rare butterfly that directly overwinters in its larval form.
Even when temperatures drop below zero, they do not choose to hibernate, but instead try to slow down the intensity of their physical activities, and quietly wait for winter to pass.
Perhaps tempered by nature's trial, the aurora swallowtail's body is noticeably more robust compared to ordinary butterflies.

The Deilephila elpenor is commonly known as the elephant hawk moth.
The word "elephant" might seem unrelated to its vibrant appearance at first glance, but it's because "elephant" is actually associated with its larval form.
While feeding, the larva stretches its body forward like an elephant's trunk instead of moving their entire body forward. Some theories suggest this unique motion is a way to conserve energy — Colloquially known as being "lazy."

A Yellowback Demoiselle's health is directly reflected through its body color.
When healthy, the blue on its body shimmers with a dreamy glow.
When unwell, the blue fades.
Despite plenty of warning signs, most owners still find themselves overwhelmed when caring for this finicky fish.

The blue blanquillo typically dwells in sandy or muddy seabeds, where it digs burrows for home or shelter.
If your aquarium suddenly experiences a "sandstorm," check carefully if a blue blanquillo has moved in.

The ornate rock lobster is a clawless lobster that can grow to enormous sizes.
During molting, it consumes its old shell to replenish needed calcium.
If other lobsters are present when this happens, the discarded shell may even trigger fights.

The redmoon snakehead refers to the red variant of the Channa nox.
With an elegant body and brilliant red coloration akin to a blood moon, it can be kept as an ornamental fish.
At the same time, it is just as delicious as the black variant, doubling as a great dish. Acing two fronts with one fish indeed.

The canary wrasse is small and cute, but like other fish from the Halichoeres genus, it has inward-curving canine teeth resembling boar tusks.
If two male canary wrasses are placed in the same tank, they will fight to the death with their sharp tusks.
Who'd think something so cute would resort to violent "boar fights" underwater?

The moon moth has a pair of gorgeous trailing tails.
Research has found that this seemingly flight-affecting structure can actually interfere with bats' echolocation system, throwing off directions for pursuing bats.
In dire situations, they can also break off these beautiful trailing tails to escape, similar to geckos.

The mantis shrimp are fierce creatures with club-like claws that can easily shatter the armor that crustaceans are so proud of. Some have even given them the nickname "thumb splitters."
However, sometimes, a "hard" nature can be countered by a "soft" approach.
The octopus, which also dwells on the sea floor, injects a paralyzing saliva into the mantis shrimp, then feasts on it with the hidden beak inside its body.

Black crabs like to hide in muddy burrows, only showing their large pincers in the face of danger.
This often leads to them losing their important pincers.
But don't worry too much! When they molt their shell next time, those important pincers will grow back.

The sixbar swordtail butterfly spirals upward in flight, similar to an ascending sword master in martial arts fantasy.
This flying method is more conducive to climbing higher, but there's currently no credible conclusion on why the sixbar swordtail seeks to "ascend" this way.

After discovering that mosquitofish prey on mosquito larvae, the species was introduced to rivers and lakes as a biological control for mosquitoes.
However, researchers soon discovered that mosquitofish also prey on frog tadpoles and other fish eggs, causing ecological damage.
What was meant to solve a mosquito problem inadvertently created a new "fish problem." A classic case of a solution backfiring.

Black tilapias belong to the Cichlidae family and are often marketed as "freshwater porgies" due to their resemblance to fish from the Sparidae family.
However, black tilapia are highly salt-tolerant and can live in brackish or even seawater. Therefore, it isn't entirely impossible for someone to catch a "freshwater porgy" from the ocean.

During the scorching summer, the crimson marsh glider will try to raise its abdomen as far up as it can, as if pointing at the sun.
In reality, it does this to align its long, narrow body with the sunlight's direction, minimizing direct heat absorption across its body surface.

Though rare in the wild, white cloud minnows are relatively easy to raise in captivity. As long as the right conditions are provided, they remain highly active.
However, special attention should be given to their feeding schedule, because overfeeding can be a problem among captive white cloud minnows, which turns their streamlined bodies into a round shape.

The red spotted porcelain crab is highly territorial and will stop other intruders from entering its domain after claiming a patch of anemone.
Despite its intimidating claws, it struggles to win fights, especially against other clawed animals. In the end, it often fails to defend the territory it worked so hard to claim.

The spiny blind lobster lives in the deep sea, where its eyes have severely deteriorated in the lightless environment.
Unable to see, it employs traps. It attempts to lure in the prey with a piece of bait between its small pincers. Sometimes, even if it ends up attracting creatures considered "colossal" by its standards, it will still meet the challenge head-on.

The ornate angelfish earns its "bellus" species name for its appearance.
However, due to environmental or individual circumstances, it can undergo sex changes during growth, transitioning from the original blue-white coloration to a blue-yellow one.
While still "bellus," this sexual dichromaticism never fails to catch novice hobbyists by surprise.

The peppermint angelfish is a small fish found in deep reef areas with an extremely high market value due to the difficulty of capturing live specimens.
For owners, even after spending a fortune to acquire one for the collection, the constant stress of having to monitor its condition makes for an exhilarating gamble.

Fireflies can control their luminosity by regulating the air entering their bodies.
When they sense danger, they will turn off their "lights" and "lie low."

The shadow bass belongs to the sunfish family. Contrary to the "sun" in their family name, they are darker in color, blending into rivers like shadows, hence their namesake.
Interestingly, some of these "shadowy" bass share the same waters as their relatives, the "sunny" bream.

The "Jezebel" in the redbase Jezebel's name is generally considered to refer to its colorful ventral appearance.
It can be seen throughout the year and does not have any particular association with festive holidays.

Sweetfish have a strong sense of territory and usually stay within their claimed areas.
Therefore, a unique "decoy fishing" method is used for sweetfish — using one sweetfish as bait in another sweetfish's territory will lure out the resident, making it easier to catch.

The moonfish is the only known warm-blooded fish species.
It generates heat by constantly flapping its pectoral fins. In a way, its method of retaining heat is similar to how we keep fanning ourselves to stay cool in summer. Great minds think alike.

The golden threadfin bream are renowned for their delicious taste, especially in regions where they are abundant.
In the past, to prevent freshly caught threadfin bream from losing their flavor, fishermen would preserve them by submerging them in sea salt-filled jars overnight. Once ashore, the fish will be ready for cooking.
Over time, this method earned threadfin bream the moniker "overnight jar."
So if you see a dish named "pan-fried overnight jar," don't worry — You're definitely not eating the jar that's used to store the fish.

The bluelined angelfish has a tiny mouth and relies on its comb-like teeth to scrape and feed on debris from coral reefs in the wild.
Although skittish by nature, it shows a great deal of interest in shrimp meat while in captivity.
It goes to say that some "gentle" dispositions are but products of circumstance.

The larvae of the crimson tip butterfly have massive bodies, capable of even mimicking a small snake to scare away predators.
However, an army of ants can easily bite and kill the strong larvae within a short time.

True to its name, the giant snakehead can easily grow over a meter in length.
In areas where it's found, mysterious "water monster" sightings are common. The "monster" behind these sightings ultimately turns out to be the voracious giant snakehead.

The heart cockle's shell is an incredibly symmetrical heart shape. The special structure was designed to house symbiotic algae.
The algae provide nutrients for the heart cockle through photosynthesis, while the cockle offers a safe haven inside its body in a mutually beneficial symbiosis.
However, the algae isn't its only food source. The cockle also filters and consumes debris in the water with its tubes for additional nutrition.

The fire urchin is entirely bright red with blue bioluminescent spots that flicker like starlight in its center. Though strikingly beautiful, being pricked by its spines causes an intense burning pain.
Because of this, many crabs will carry fire urchins on their backs, turning them into their personal "flame shield."

As its name suggests, unlike other starfish, the six-rayed star has six arms.
When it was first discovered, researchers thought it to be a mutated specimen of some armless starfish. However, as more and more six-rayed stars were found, they realized that they had stumbled upon a mysterious new species.

The rainbow mantis shrimp has stunning colors, and like other less colorful mantis shrimps, it's also prized for its delicious meat.
That's why its beauty hasn't spared it from the seafood markets.

When compared to males of the species, female butterfly dragonflies' wings lack some metallic texture and sense of power.
Possibly due to this power difference, female butterfly dragonflies will adopt a strategy of vertically dropping to the ground and playing dead when pursued by unwanted males, avoiding untimely "marriage."

Despite its name, the green sea urchin isn't always green.
Purple, dark red, and even white-spotted "green" urchins have been recorded in various regions.
The reasons behind this color variation remain a topic of ongoing academic research.

The pupa of the bluebottle butterfly will mimic the appearance of camphor tree leaves.
However, bluebottles do not exclusively choose camphor trees for pupation. But in terms of the bluebottle species' population, slight "mismatches" in pupal camouflage seem to quite acceptable.

The sanke koi are a variety of koi fish.
Koi can evolve into colorful variants in their natural environment even without human intervention.
However, these brightly colored koi are often easy prey to predators in the wild. Therefore, when selectively bred multicolored koi are reintroduced to the wild, they typically "revert to their true forms" after a few generations, thanks to natural selection.

The red-line torpedo barb is often perceived as gentle and timid, similar to small tetras.
In reality, it belongs to the Cyprinidae family and can grow to over 10 cm in length.
The "all-grown-up" red-line torpedo barb typically sheds its timid nature and becomes an aggressive predator, actively hunting smaller fish and shrimp.

The rose danio's brilliant coloration is only on full display under very specific conditions. Otherwise, it looks just like an ordinary and unremarkable rice paddy fish.
For the longest time, this extraordinary little fish went unnoticed, but as the saying goes, "gold will always shine." Once discovered by "talent scouts," the rose danio's value naturally skyrocketed.

The rainbow porgy is a red variant resulting from the crossbreeding of different tilapia subspecies.
Despite their colorful appearance, they are still tilapia in essence, and there is a chance for their offspring to revert to the original black coloration.

Bay salmon are known for their vibrant orange flesh, which is quite the standout trait among fish.
This color comes from the astaxanthin in their diet, with higher levels resulting in brighter orange flesh.
However, this can't be the only criterion for judging the flavor of the salmon.

Unlike the typical spiny sea urchins, the tuxedo sea urchin has short, humble, and non-toxic spines, appearing harmless.
Perhaps due to this insecurity, it has a peculiar habit of sneakily carrying coral on its back.

Five-bar swordtails often gather around mud puddles formed after rain.
This behavior is to replenish the salt and minerals their bodies need.
These butterflies aren't the only insects attracted to the mud puddle. Despite being "armed" with "swords," they are but frail butterflies, and won't show any aggression toward the other insects that have come to share.

Silk moths only feed during their larval stage.
After metamorphosis, they lose their mouthparts and can only rely on the reserve of nutrients accumulated during their larval stage.
For silk moths, emergence is a bittersweet "coming of age" that heralds the approaching end.

The phoenix barb is most recognizable by the "blush" on its gill covers.
It's a sign of maturity. Before reaching full size, it looks almost identical to the grass carp, with no distinctive coloration on its body.
The market value of a phoenix barb is much higher than that of a grass carp's, though, so there's no need to worry about getting the wrong fish when buying grass carp.

Hermit crabs have very soft abdomens and must hide in shells for protection.
Sometimes, to find the right "house," they would even murder the original owner of the place — a hapless sea snail whose shell just so happens to be perfect for the hermit.

The adult Jade Baron is extremely beautiful, but its larvae have astonishingly exaggerated spikes that, from a distance, can even be mistaken for a green centipede.
With this unique larval form, when they crawl on leaves, they almost perfectly align with the leaf's veins, avoiding detection by predators this way.

Large yellow croakers have two large otoliths in their heads.
Sound waves from striking hard objects can travel underwater and resonate with these otoliths, stunning the fish and causing them to lose direction and float to the surface.
In the past, fishermen used this clever method to hunt them. However, in order to protect the yellow croaker population, this fishing method and similar ones have all been prohibited.

The emperor angelfish is a very typical coral reef fish with dramatic differences between its juvenile and adult forms.
However, in captivity, it may retain its juvenile "blue and white rings" look even when biologically mature.
One wonders if such an individual would still be considered a baby by its wild peers?

The forest caterpillar hunter are famous forest hunters.
They will use their powerful mandibles to grab prey, tear through their bodies, and drain their bodily fluids until the prey becomes an empty husk.
Surprisingly, this feeding method has not earned them any "vampiric" nicknames.

The colorful pink square anthias are, in a broader sense, a type of grouper. In some regions, they are more likely to be eaten than kept as ornamental fish.
Interestingly, they used to belong to the genus Anthias, meaning "fish," before being moved under the genus Pseudanthias, meaning "false fish."

The azure metallic hedge blue's wings have completely different patterns on their front and back sides.
Some argue that the vibrant colors on the wing's front are used for courtship among their own species, whereas the duller colors on the back allow for better camouflage when wings are folded for resting, helping them escape predators.
However, if we consider the overall behavioral logic, then this explanation clearly falls short. After all, butterflies can't tell who's observing their wings.
The golden wonder killifish isn't particularly large, but it has a disproportionately wider mouth compared to other small fish, allowing it to easily "inhale" smaller fish in one go.

Blackspot tuskfish are known for their distinctive "tusks," which they use to crush hard-shelled prey like sea urchins. This trait inspired the fishing method where sea urchins are used as bait for the blackspot tuskfish.
So, if you reel in and see a sea urchin on the hook, consider that it might not be a sea urchin you caught, but rather, a tuskfish that you missed.

When the bean-shaped fist crab is threatened, it flops to the ground and becomes motionless, "abandoning all hope" in the face of danger.
This lethargic attitude extends to other aspects of its life too, as it prefers scavenging dead fish, shellfish, and crabs on the beach over hunting live prey.

The deep-sea coral crab remains a mysterious species.
Generally, coral crabs live in symbiosis with coral in near-shore coral reef areas. However, deep-sea coral crabs were first discovered in depths exceeding 200 meters.
Exactly what led to their separation from their kin and their dive into the depths remains a topic for research.

The multicolored spiny oyster boasts an enormous size that far exceeds the common perception of shells.
When open, it resembles a gaping, hungering maw, evoking existential horror.
But in fact, despite its size, it only feeds on plankton. Truly a "gentle giant."

The empress butterfly is a large butterfly that, contrary to the general impression, flies very quickly. Even dragonflies have trouble catching it.
But sometimes, it becomes so absorbed in drinking tree sap that it neglects its surroundings, falling right into the predator's trap.

Tiger prawns typically live in seagrass beds around 200 meters deep.
They are large and delicious, so merchants began aquaculture research early on, and accidentally discovered that they can be crossbred with the tiger shrimp.
Regrettably, tiger prawns are worth much more than tiger shrimps, and crossbred individuals, despite having tiger prawn genes, can only settle for tiger shrimp pricing.

Ground beetles are carnivorous insects, with most species adopting an active hunting strategy. They are on the list of rare insects that can reverse the food chain by preying on small vertebrates.
Even if swallowed by frogs, they are capable of chewing their way out and turning the tables on their predator.
However, one can rest assured that as long as the ground beetles stay as they are, most vertebrates won't be sweating over a new survival crisis.

Sockeye salmon are born in freshwater and migrate to the ocean as they mature. Their bodies will also turn a silvery gray, better suited for life in open waters.
During spawning season, they migrate back to the rivers to spawn, and their body color will change again to a bright red.
When the "red tide" emerges in the rivers, you'll know that the sockeye have come home again.

The true lobster's hard shell serves as exceptional armor, securing the species its ecological niche in the unforgiving nature.
However, thanks to the very same hard armor, they only have a brief window for mating between molting and the hardening of their new shell.

Golden trout are a selectively bred variant of rainbow trout, distinguished only by their golden coloration. The rest of their biological traits are identical to the rainbow trout's.
The golden coloration is a dominant trait, so even when crossbred with other trout species, their offspring often retain the golden hue.
This means that a golden trout caught in the wild won't necessarily be a "24k" golden trout.

The red-breasted wrasse is an edible fish.
But its resemblance to the ornamental harlequin tuskfish and ease of care have made it popular in the aquarium scene, contributing to its unexpected change of location from seafood market to pet shops.

The black chafer beetle has a plate-like sensor on its antennae that can detect the scents of plants. By relying on this special "nose," they can precisely locate their favorite crops and feast with great delight.

Rainbow trout have significant economic value. In some well-established aquaculture regions, rainbow trout fry are aerially "bombed" into water bodies using planes to complete stocking tasks. 
It seems that turning an ordinary plane into a torpedo bomber might only require a few rainbow trout.

Unicolored scarab beetles survive by licking tree sap, but their mouthparts are insufficient to pierce through tough tree bark, so they can only wait for an "opportunity" to get the food they need.
In a sense, it's also kind of like "relying on heaven to provide a meal."

The small yellow croaker is not a juvenile of the large yellow croaker.
However, it's easy to confuse the two as being of the same species from their names and appearances.
Hence, a suggestion was made to refer to the smaller large yellow croakers, "small large yellow croakers," and the larger small yellow croakers, "large small yellow croakers."
But that just seems to complicate things even more.

Striped hermit crabs can grow much larger than common hermit crabs.
Therefore, compared to other hermit crabs, they are more enthusiastic about hunting sea snails for a more comfortable "house."

The candy-striped shrimp feeds on debris picked up inside and around anemones, which helps keep the environment around anemones clean and comfortable. In return, the anemones offer protection with their stinging cells, making the two a classic symbiotic pair.
However, symbiosis doesn't guarantee safety and ease of mind for the candy-striped shrimp.
After all, there have been cases where these shrimps were found half-digested in some fish's belly.

Tiger butterflies can convert different plant materials they ingest into substances that benefit them.
For example, during their larval stage, they store toxins obtained from a liana known as Graphistemma pictum to ward off predators.
As adults, male tiger butterflies feed on rattleweed to produce pheromones that attract females.
Compared to the traditional "feed, absorb, excrete" cycle, tiger butterflies seem to go above and beyond on this energy absorption business.

The skunk cleaner shrimp will select a coral reef to set up its "clinic."
When fish stop by, the shrimp will approach and clean dead skin and parasites off their bodies.
While some fish appreciate the service, others see the poor shrimp as a delivered meal.

Although jewel beetles do not have the kabuto beetle's magnificent horn, they already have a sharp mandible in their larval stage that can directly crack tree barks.
Lacking any visible "weapons" yet still causing massive "damage," the saying "never judge a beetle by its horn" couldn't be more true.

The Neptune lobster is a moderately large deep-sea species.
Before gaining popularity, they were occasionally caught in nets meant for the scarlet prawn.
After becoming the most sought-after star species, fishing boats changed their strategies, and the Neptune lobster suddenly became the "protagonist" in the nets.
But this is not really a good thing.

Whitetail dascyllus are popular saltwater aquarium fish.
They are highly competitive among themselves. When a group of similarly sized dascyllus gather in a body of water, the strongest will gradually grow larger and become male.
This transformation is one of the joys of keeping the species.

The honeycomb stingray is a massive species of stingray.
Under normal circumstances, they lie buried in sandy seafloors, waiting to ambush their prey with only their spiracles and eyes exposed.
Imagine a giant creature suddenly flipping over in the dark depths, engulfing a small and unsuspecting passerby, then vanishing without a trace... The honeycomb stingray might just be the inspiration for those sea monster legends.

When foreign substances enter a pearl oyster, the oyster secretes layers of nacre and calcium carbonate that envelops the substance to form a pearl.
Composition wise, pearls are mostly calcium carbonate, just like the oyster itself.

Although the milu stag beetle is not impressive in size, its unique appearance makes it the coveted star species among insect collectors.
Unfortunately, the natural lifespan of the milu stag beetle is short. Not long after their first meeting, enthusiasts will have to bid the beetle a final goodbye.

The golden puffer can live in pure freshwater environments and is one of the rare members of the Tetraodontidae family that doesn't inflate.
As they grow, their bodies become increasingly flat, resembling the ocean sunfish.
However, no matter how similar they are in appearance, the bottom-dwelling golden puffer will never float on the water's surface like a pancake.

The golden pinecone fish's scales have evolved into hard armor. Some bioluminescent bacteria cling to them and swim around with the fish.
If you encounter a glowing "pineapple" while diving, remember to stay calm — it's likely just a harmless pinecone fish.

The flat rock crab got its name for its flat appearance.
Some scholars believe it evolved smooth claws to better scrape algae off reefs.
As the crab matures and grows in strength, these smooth claws become deadly weapons for hunting small fish and invertebrates.

The longtail butterfly ray may look soft and timid, but in fact, its mouth contains a curved jaw lined with densely packed, small, and sharp teeth that continue to increase in number as it grows.
This trait is similar to sharks, which proves its extremely close genetic relationship to the species.

Honey bees have a strict social hierarchy.
When the queen bee is strong and a worker bee lays eggs in secret, it will anxiously consume and get rid of them. However, if the queen bee is weak, then the worker bees capable of laying eggs may opt for regicide and replace her.

Black carp enjoy eating hard-shelled snails. Over time, they have evolved a unique, hardened growth in their throat, known as the "black carp stone."
These stones are highly prized in the gemstone market. However, many people don't realize that they're not gems, just fish teeth.

Although the royal angelfish is an omnivorous species, they are highly dependent on sponges.
Their health condition worsens after prolonged sponge deficiency in their diet, one of the main reasons why they are difficult to breed in captivity.

The oleander hawk moth derives its name from its diet of oleander plants.
To intimidate predators, the moth's larvae have two fluorescent blue eye spots on their head, reminiscent of alien species in science fiction — the ones that occasionally stir up "disturbances."

The taimen is also known as the common taimen.
However, it is anything but "common" as a large carnivorous fish.
The taimen's legendary size and elusive nature once led to rumors that it was the authentic "lake cryptid." However, like most cryptid legends, without concrete evidence, the taimen's cryptid status remains speculative.

The regal tang will reach its bright yellow tail into intricate coral branches and use the branches as leverage to anchor itself.
When an intruder threatens to drag it out of the coral, it will "play dead" by tilting to one side while still hooked onto the coral.
This behavior has earned it the odd nickname "hanging fish."

The Atergatis integerrimus, commonly known as the red egg crab, closely resembles the edible crab in appearance. But unlike the edible crab, red egg crabs are highly toxic due to their diet and cannot be consumed.
The "integerrimus" in its name describes its "whole and complete" shape. For such a toxic crab species, perhaps "wholesome" isn't quite the right description.
If we are to rename it based on characteristics, then perhaps it should be "Atergatis periculosus" instead.

Silver pomfrets primarily prey on jellyfish, and during initial attempts at artificially breeding the species, feeding became the main challenge.
Later, researchers developed a method where jellyfish were first fed with feed, and then the pomfret would eat the jellyfish. This allowed the silver pomfret to get accustomed to the taste of the feed, eventually solving the problem.
It seems that the "Trojan horse" tactic can be quite useful beyond just siege warfare.

Only male kabuto beetles grow an impressive, protruding horn.
This horn is typically used in battles against other males. Despite its heroic appearance, the horn is virtually useless in the beetle's daily life and feeding. Even with such an impressive "weapon," kabuto beetles still obtain nutrition by licking decaying fruits and tree sap like the rest of their Scarabaeidae kin.

The constable butterfly gets its name from the dazzling "badges" on its wings.
These dazzling "badges" are created by light reflecting off the scales on the wings.
One could say that the "badges" displayed represent true "authority" in every sense.
Fortunately, you are highly unlikely to get into trouble with this particular "authority."

Grass carp are named for their herbivorous habits, but this diet isn't persistent throughout its life cycle.
During their juvenile stage, grass carp primarily feed on invertebrates.
It's only when they grow to about the size of a bottle cap that they fully transition to a plant-based diet.
So, don't be surprised if you see a grass carp eating meat — It might just be reminiscing about its babyhood.

Rice fish are highly adaptable to different environments and can be found anywhere from salt fields to hot springs.
They have even achieved the remarkable feat of laying and hatching eggs in space.
Despite their excellent adaptability, rice fish are extremely sensitive to toxins. Even the tiniest pollution can wipe them out.

The blue trim parrotfish has its unique beak-like mouth to thank for being able to tear through hard coral as if they were potato chips.
The ingested coral calcium generally cannot be digested and will be excreted afterward. Over time, these form beautiful "white sand beaches" on the seafloor or coastline.

Sea urchins often leave the impression of being stationary creatures, but they move around slowly with their tube feet and spines.
Some gastropod sea snails prey on sea urchins, so sometimes you'll catch slow-motion chases between the two on the sea floor.

The moon crab is an expert at sand diving with specialized legs that double as paddles for swift swimming.
Despite all that, it often ends up ashore in fishing nets. Because of its mediocre taste, it's usually sold in seafood markets in the same tank as other miscellaneous crabs.

Mantises are natural-born hunters. Many adore them for their clean hunting technique and eccentric appearance, making them an extremely popular species of insect.
To everyone's surprise, however, there has been plenty of evidence proving that the handsome mantis shares common ancestry with the repulsive cockroach.

The green flat-horned leaf beetle is extremely cowardly. At the slightest disturbance, it will play dead and roll off plants onto the ground.
Because these beetles often break out in swarms, the strange "candy rain" phenomenon may occur after a gust.

The orchid mantis is a mantis with highly specialized physiological characteristics due to its environment.
Despite having "orchid" in its name, it doesn't necessarily live exclusively on orchids.
Therefore, don't be too surprised if you run into one at an unexpected location.

The rainbow parrotfish is large in size but has a gentle and non-aggressive temperament.
It evolved to have brilliant colors to help it better hide among coral reefs.
However, it accumulates ciguatoxins by consuming poisonous algae. Those who excessively "bully" this mild-mannered fish might find themselves on the receiving end of its revenge.

The Helena Morpho's dazzling blue wings make it one of the most famous butterflies in the world.
Surprisingly, despite its gorgeous appearance, it prefers feeding on rotting fruit and animal droppings to flowers.

The dark snakehead bears a striking resemblance to the northern snakehead, commonly known as fishzilla.
Those who have kept both species say that dark snakeheads tend to be more docile than northern snakeheads and rarely display aggressive behavior behind the glass.
However, given their longer snout, it's likely that they depend less on their vision. Therefore, what keepers perceive as "more docile" might simply be a case of poor vision.

The beautiful banded coral shrimps are typically kept in captivity as cleaning shrimps.
While their keepers hope they'll help remove parasites from fish, once in captivity, the coral shrimps often change their feeding strategy and compete for fish feed instead. This competition over food and territory might even lead to them biting and killing other cleaner shrimps in the process. Quite the temperamental beauty, indeed.

The thorny oyster appeared on dining tables as a delicacy long before hamburgers.
It doesn't require complex preparation. Simple seasoning is enough to bring out its irresistible, savory taste. However, note that during certain periods, toxins can accumulate in the shellfish and potentially poison their consumer. Therefore, one should pay attention to the seasons when eating this delicacy.

The neon tetra relies on an external light source for their fluorescence.
When they're in dimly lit environments, the fluorescence on their bodies fades. In other words, you can control the "light switch" on them by turning the lights on and off.

The unique, vibrant purple color of the purple scallops makes them highly popular in seashell trading.
But at the same time, in areas where they're abundant, they're usually sold in food markets as ordinary scallops.

The angel red shrimp dwells on sandy seabeds, where its burrowing behavior has been frequently observed.
Unfortunately, due to its tendency to quickly perish out of water, there are currently no reliable farming methods for the species, making it difficult for researchers to study its habits in depth.

The red hind usually hides in rocky crevices or near the seafloor, ambushing its prey with surprise attacks.
However, this strategy of staying still most of the time and only striking at crucial moments has led it to develop a "wait-and-see" habit, overlooking the creeping, silent dangers around. While it waits for an octopus, another hunter might be just behind.

In classical legends, the ribbed cockle was the vessel that gave birth to goddesses, which is why its shape is often used as a decorative element in many classical paintings and architecture.
However, for the cockle, it's just being its ordinary self, lying quietly and inconspicuously on the seabed.

The Oscar's continent-like patterns are visually striking and serve as one of its most distinctive features.
Unlike actual maps with their strict cartographic standards, Oscar's patterns are determined by genetics and can't be proven to correspond to any real locations. Thus, the chances of locating actual treasures this way are pretty slim.

The cushion star is known for having the perfect star shape.
However, as an echinoderm, it also possesses unexpected "randomness."
For instance, you might occasionally spot one with only four arms that grew into the perfect square instead.

Sally lightfoot crabs often scuttle in groups between rocks against surging tides — a movement tactic that helps them avoid predators as much as possible.
These highly active creatures aren't strictly vegetarian. Sometimes, they'll even snack on ticks off marine iguanas to supplement their diet.

The six-spot ground beetle primarily feeds on ants. They can mimic the ants' chemical scent and make the colony accept them as one of their own, all the while feasting freely in the nest.
Not only do they enjoy such free meals, but they're also more than happy to actively hunt down prey much larger than themselves for a "change of taste."

The ropefish belongs to the Polypteriformes order, whose species are quite different from what we typically think of as "fish" from the ray-finned group.
The ropefish can "stand" using its pectoral fins and breathe air directly. With its elongated body and subtle fins, it looks more like a snake than a fish.
But don't worry — accidentally stepping on one won't make you jump at the sight of ropes for the next ten years.

Unlike the true lobster, pink spiny lobsters don't have powerful, meaty claws. They rely more on their tail muscles to move quickly, which gives their tail meat a unique texture.
And that's how a great dish was born.

Sunset Moths are diurnal moths.
Initially, biologists classified them as swallowtail butterflies due to their rod-like antennae. It wasn't until more details were discovered in specimens that they were properly categorized in the Uraniidae family.
Such mix-ups due to species looking too similar are actually quite common in biological taxonomy.

To store more energy, Goliath beetle larvae prefer protein-rich foods. Their indiscriminate appetite for protein means they'll readily accept fishing bait and even pet food like dog kibble.
However, once they metamorphose into adult beetles, they develop an exclusive "sweet tooth" for nectar, fruits, and the like.

While leatherjacket fish and the delicious horse mackerel both belong to the Carangidae family, the leatherjacket's larger size offers better meat yield and easier catch. This should theoretically make it a star competitor in fish markets against the mackerels.
In reality, however, due to its meat having a strange, oily taste, it's largely ignored by the masses.

The whiptail stingray can be trained to display dog-like, friendly behaviors such as accepting food, receiving hugs, and even rolling over for belly rubs.
However, watch out for the <style=ItemHighlight>venomous</style> stings on its tail while giving it scritches.

The bluecheek butterflyfish catches the eye instantly with its gleaming, luminous body.
For experienced aquarists, keeping them healthy is fairly straightforward — stable water quality, adequate space, nutritious food, and the willingness to accept the ongoing upkeep required for corals in the tank.

Magnificent anemone shrimp aren't great at living alone. They rely on sea anemones for protection and share a symbiotic relationship with them.
They're usually immune to the anemone's poisonous sting cells, but their soft bodies lose this immunity when it's time to molt, forcing them to temporarily move away.
This becomes their "rite of passage."

The biofluorescent color emitted by the blue tang is affected by external light.
For instance, some anglers have caught blue tang that appeared green. This is likely due to the UV intensity at the time of the catch.
The impact of this color change within the species remains unclear, but it's unlikely for the blue tang to see their companions turn green while underwater.

Piranhas typically move in schools, and for a long time, this distinctive behavior was seen as evidence of their cooperative hunting habits. However, recent studies suggest that their group behavior is primarily a defense mechanism against predators.
All things considered, there's no need to worry too much about their fierce nature. After all, you're more likely to encounter them as a dish on your table.

The zebra mantis shrimp is the largest species among the stomatopods.
However, size can be both an advantage and a limitation — its relatively weak walking legs struggle to support its heavy body, making it impossible to move without the buoyancy of seawater.

Red false acraea is a butterfly species that closely resembles butterflies of the Acraea genus.
They live in the same areas as acraeas, and the two species even mimic each other's appearance, making it difficult to distinguish between them with the naked eye.

The Blue Neon Cichlid is relatively small in size, which puts them at a disadvantage in natural competition. To cope with this, they typically adopt strategies of evasion and concealment, quickly hiding in protective rock caves at the slightest disturbance.
However, should they feel that their "ownership" of the cave is threatened, they can display rare bursts of aggression.

The owl butterfly, as its name suggests, has wing patterns that mimic the appearance of an owl to scare away predators.
Of course, they have no way of knowing their wings look like owls. If anything, this "winning pattern" just happened to emerge this way through generations of natural selection.

Green-Banded Urania Moths are diurnal moths.
They closely resemble the sunset moth in appearance, but in reality, the two originate from vastly different regions. If one were to trace their familial relationship, they may have to start all the way from the evolutionary history of the Uraniidae family.

While cape honey bees don't look much different from common honey bees, generations of evolution in dry and volatile environments have given them stronger disease resistance, reproductive capabilities, and a more aggressive temperament than their cousins.
Nevertheless, the casualties caused by cape honey bees are largely exaggerated by the media. Under the scientific principle that "there are always more solutions than problems," the "problems" posed by cape honey bees have yet to escalate beyond resolution.

The blackfin pearlfish aren't particularly difficult to breed in captivity.
Once the "nursery" has been set up with peat soil and shelters with hiding spots are added, a mature pair of blackfin pearlfish will soon begin their breeding process. The eggs, buried in the peat soil, can survive out of water in a dry state for a reasonably long time.
While the blackfin pearlfish have relatively short natural lifespans, this unique breeding strategy is their way of ensuring survival of the fittest.

As one of the largest cichlids, the speckled peacock bass has a voracious appetite.
When food is abundant, their young can quickly grow to an impressive size through constant feeding. This often leads inexperienced keepers to worry about upgrading to a larger tank after just a few months of care.

There isn't much research on the orange-blotched pacu, and its specific habits remain unclear.
However, what we do know is that adult specimens are larger than other common pacus. In captivity, they're just as voracious as their cousins, eagerly devouring anything from small fish to cabbage.

The four-line wrasse is commonly known as a cleaner fish that provides cleaning services to other fish, which is why many saltwater aquarium enthusiasts choose to keep them.
However, most people are shocked to discover that when these fish grow up, the adults switch to feeding on coral polyps, causing devastating damage to coral colonies in the tank.

The yellowfin tuna has a diverse diet that includes fish, crustaceans, and cephalopods.
Research teams analyzing their fatty acid composition discovered that the larger a yellowfin tuna's "spear" is, the greater the tendency for them to switch to other fish as primary prey.
This change is believed to be a way of avoiding competition with their young over food, or explained as their way of "caring" for the juveniles.

Anchovies are difficult to keep fresh after being caught, and so for a long time, they were overlooked for their perceived low economic value.
However, once fish oil production and canning preservation technology improved, anchovies suddenly became an important commercial fish.
Though for the anchovies themselves, this "status upgrade" might not be something to celebrate.

The history of using the metallic wood-boring beetle's vibrant wing cases as expensive decorations dates back a long time. Its spectacular size, compared to other beetles, has made it a symbol of wealth and power in some cultures.
However, in certain other cultures, it's simply a type of food that can be roasted and eaten.

The flat-clawed hermit crab might look nothing spectacular, but its incredibly long lifespan and easy living requirements made it one of the most popular pet hermit crab species.
Looks like you don't need to look flashy to become a star after all.

Compared to honey bees, bumblebees are more robust in size, and you can often spot them getting "stuck" on flower stamens, looking absolutely adorable. Although they're too chubby to squeeze into the flower centers, their overall pollination abilities are actually better than honey bees. Some farms even specifically raise bumblebees to pollinate their crops.
